title: How to Set Up a Photograph

steps.headline: Put some thought into it.
steps.description: Are you taking a picture of the parade, or of the float in the parade? Fill the frame with the subject. A good example to consider is taking pictures of someone in a room. If you are positioned too far away, the room usually becomes more prominent than the person you were trying to photograph.

steps.headline: Don't shoot into the sun.
steps.description: All you will get is a silhouette. Unless that's what you want. You can get a good shot, but it may take better preparation, and a fill flash.

steps.headline: Look for 'naturally occurring' frames.
steps.description: These are landmarks and other things, like windows, bridges, trees, etc. Whatever creates a frame around your subject.

steps.headline: Try different angles.
steps.description: Shoot on the ground, from the ground, oblique angles, etc. For instance, if you're photographing a small child, or even an animal, get down on their level. Don’t only shoot from your own point of view.

steps.headline: Improve the odds of getting a good shot by using a tripod.
Lighting control.
steps.description: If you are taking photographs indoors, consider setting up adequate lighting if you want to take a perfect still shot.

steps.headline: Know your camera well.
steps.description: Research all its functions so you can use them with ease.
